I am not an expert, so feel free to fact-check me, but here's an interesting tale:


The laws of thermodynamics could be seen as having some pretty depressing things to say, such as predicting the eventual heat death of the universe because "entropy tends to increase in an isolated system".


This means there are no processes that won't eventually eat themselves without external input and that, eventually, all of the stuff in the universe is likely to lose touch as thoroughly as the members of an Introverts United club with a strict IRL-only meeting policy.


But another way of seeing all this is, *phew!*, thank goodness the processes in this universe are so "spilly" or else I wouldn't be getting enough wave data to convert into the experience of me living anywhere (much less the gloriously wave-dense Eden I currently live in).


We cottoned onto thermodynamics because some 19th century fat cats got kinky at the prospect of free energy during the industrial revolution and hired some 19th century spods to figure out how to make that junk work.


The 19th century spods had bad news for them (sorry lads, turns out it's "impossible to design any system that is free of energy dissipation"), and the field of thermodynamics was born. But there was a smidge of good news. Perpetual machines and whatnot were a no-go, but increasing the efficiency of machines by a significant margin to reduce the loss of energy to unwanted vibrational by-products such as heat, light and sound etc was a definite goer.


To wrap this tale up, could it be that the humongous amount of undetectable dark matter that pops up in our figures when we're figuring out galaxy stats is actually proof of v intelligent (if perhaps a little selfish) aliens who have figured out how to harvest energy by radically increasing the efficiency of their machines to the point where the amount of energy that radiates out from the process is currently undetectable by us other than by the gravitational effect of the mass? Or perhaps that there is just a naturally occurring process which generates this kind of effect as an emergent property at vast scales?


I dunno, I'm not one of those omniscient story tellers you get in novels. I'm defo one of the unreliable ones (as hinted at at the start of this tome). It’s not really science until someone figures out a way to test this stuff.


Intriguing though, ain’t it.

I really doubt the existence of dark matter. It is supposed to ignore collision with basically anything but still cause and be affected by gravity? It rather sounds absurd and unlikely. Like a quickfix to something we did not yet understand yet.

I rather think the following is the case: As you know, gravity has the effect to pull things to the object exerting it, but also being pulled by the object. The more mass an object has, the more likely it is to be affected by gravity and affect other objects. Imagine there is a planet flying across space just slightly beyond the gravitational reach of our solar system - it would just fly straight away. If it had more mass (~2 to 100 times more), it might have been in reach of the suns gravitational force, thus being affected by its pull -- but also exerting the same amount of force to the sun (but due to the difference of mass the sun would be pulled much less), which might cause the planet to orbit.

Orbiting is imagined as something which has a fixed object of higher mass in the middle and an object of lower mass orbiting it, but actually the fixed object is not unaffected by it, it will move slightly along with it.

The galaxy's coherence of stars is explained by dark matter, but I think we just did not got the concept of gravity right. It distorts light and time - but what if this phenomenon is not exclusive to black holes and insignificant everywhere else, but rather fundamental to the understanding of it? What if the view we have all around us is just more and more distorted, and we interpret the wrong data? Not only light is affected, but it is said that time too. And what if time is not even affected, but instead space is distorted by gravity in a way, which causes it to "contain more place", which looks like time goes slower? What if a black hole just expands the space existing in its surroundings, which makes matter and light travel thousand or more times "further" than before?

I also heard, orbiting planets are said to fly in straight lines, but space is distorted around stars which causes the route to go actually in circles.

I think, before we claim there is something we cannot measure, and a hella lot of it, first let's understand gravity and its effects on space, time and light on the large scale. Because that might lead to the real answer why galaxies can hold their stars together - by their shared gravitational force - and maybe because stars which did not happen to stick to it just flew away long time ago.

To say it doesn't interact with light isn't completely true. The one thing it does to light is change its path with the gravity it creates.

Picture a truck carrying cars on a highway with a car driving off the back of the truck at the same speed every 3 seconds.  A car passes an observer behind the truck at the same speed, but the speed of the truck changes the frequency at which they see the cars go by. Cars are like light, C is like the speed of the cars, and the frequency at which they pass the observer is like the frequency of the light wave.  The Doppler effect measures how often cars go by, not their individual speed.

I'll try: Scientists see the universe operating in a certain way which, according to our current understanding, should require more mass than they currently detect. In other words, due to how they see things working, it looks as though there's a bunch of missing mass in universe. So, they guess that there must be a lot of mass out there that they are currently unable to detect - they think it's there, but they can't see it. They call this undetected mass "dark matter." Except that the aether had no observational evidence.  Dark Matter, on the other hand, is supported by enormous amounts of evidence via gravitational lensing.

We can easily calculate the density of our region of the universe - it's usually a problem given to students in the first chapter of a cosmology textbook, it's so simple.

But, trying to add up the mass of all of the visible matter in the universe gives only 5% of the necessary amount.  

There are mountains of evidence for Dark Matter, as it can be observed via gravitational lensing, how it curves light.  The most notable example is the Bullet Cluster.
No, dark matter simply doesn't interact with photons, the force carriers of the electromagnetic force.  One form of hot dark matter, the neutrino, is invisible as it doesn't scatter photons.

Well, the extreme gravitational lensing from the Bullet Cluster seems to suggest the existence of dark matter, and refute any theories of modified gravity.  Also, we've already discovered a form of hot dark matter known as the neutrino, it only seems natural that there exists a lumpy, cold form.

But, of course, it's science.  You can never fully confirm something, you can only show it is consistent with observation.  And as of now, there is no explanation better than dark matter.
